questions.question_text:
A company uses Exchange Online.
A user reports they are not receiving emails with attachments from known senders.
You need to troubleshoot the issue.
Which two policies should you review? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
A & C is Correct
A&C Anti Malware supports Common Attachments Filtering. Safe Attachments provides protection against malicious links & attachments.

Selected Answer: AC
It would be useful to know why both of you think "BC" is correct. This question is about emails with attachments. If I go to Microsoft Admin Center -> Show All -> Security -> Email and Collaboration -> Policies and Rules -> Threat Policies I can see Anti-spam, Anti-malware, and Safe Attachments. If I open Anti-malware, I see lots of options pertaining to attachments. If I open Anti-spam, the word "attachment" does not appear anywhere in the process. Makes me wonder if someone is trying to pollute the website with false answers. But at present, the answer is "A" (Anti-malware) and "C" (Safe Attachments) since both of those pertain to attachments, whereas AntiSpam does not.
imo it's BC

Selected Answer: BC
i: Anti-malware, Anti-malware policies are used to help protect your organization against malware and other malicious software. While Anti-malware policies can help protect your organization against malware, it is less likely that this is causing the problem since the attachments are not being received.
A&C are correct

Thanks to MatheusX86. From the link he shared: After the recipient rate limit is reached, messages can't be sent from the mailbox until the number of recipients that were sent messages in the past 24 hours drops below the limit. For example, a user sends an email message to 5000 recipients at 09:00 AM, then sends another message to 2500 recipients at 10:00 AM, and then sends another message to 2500 recipients at 11:00 AM, hitting the limit of 10,000 messages. The user won't be able to send messages again until 09:00 AM the next day.
Agree.
Agreed, correct~

Resposta correta.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/servicedescriptions/exchange-online-service-description/exchange-online-limits?redirectedfrom=MSDN

questions.question_text:
A company uses Exchange Online.
A user reports receiving the following non-delivery report (NDR) when sending an email:
//IMG//

What should you do?

choices.D: Increase the Maximum size of a message sent value.
choices.C: Instruct the sender to reduce the email size and resend the email.
choices.B: Instruct the sender to wait 24 hours before resending the email.
choices.A: Increase the Maximum number of recipients in a message value.

questions.question_text:
A company uses Exchange Online.
The company configures an SMTP relay device. Users report they are unable to send email through the relay device.
You need to ensure that the relay device can send email by using SMTP AUTH.
Which two actions should you perform? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

comments.content:
I believe A and B are the best choices. Port 587 everyone on agrees.
The reason for B is SMTP AUTH requires authentication from a user in Exchange Online, thus a you need a licensed 365 user to be able to do this. So this is more inline with option one in the link you provided.

discussion.content:
Got it:
Requirements for SMTP AUTH client submission
1. Mailbox: You must have a licensed Microsoft 365 or Office 365 mailbox to send email from.
2. Port: Port 587 (recommended) or port 25 is required and must be unblocked on your network. Some network firewalls or ISPs block ports, especially port 25, because that's the port that email servers use to send mail.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/mail-flow-best-practices/how-to-set-up-a-multifunction-device-or-application-to-send-email-using-microsoft-365-or-office-365#option-2-send-mail-directly-from-your-printer-or-application-to-microsoft-365-or-office-365-direct-send

A. Configure the network firewall to allow traffic on port 443.
C. Configure the network firewall to allow traffic on port 587.

Explanation:

To allow SMTP AUTH to work through an SMTP relay device, you need to configure the firewall to allow traffic on port 587, which is the default port used for SMTP submission with authentication. Additionally, port 443 may need to be opened if the SMTP relay device requires a secure SSL/TLS connection for SMTP authentication.

Option B is incorrect because instructing users to specify a different email address would not resolve the issue with the SMTP relay device.

Option D is incorrect because configuring a licensed Microsoft 365 mailbox on the relay device is not required for SMTP AUTH to work.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/clients-and-mobile-in-exchange-online/authenticated-client-smtp-submission

choices.A: Configure the network firewall to allow traffic on port 443.
choices.C: Configure the network firewall to allow traffic on port 587.
choices.D: Configure a licensed Microsoft 365 mailbox on the relay device.
choices.B: Instruct users to specify a different email address when sending email.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Agree with others. Search & Purge needed and only available with Org Mgr.

Selected Answer: D
Organization Management. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/ediscovery-assign-permissions?view=o365-worldwide#rbac-roles-related-to-ediscovery

Selected Answer: D
Need to be member of Org Management for search and delete (Search and Purge)
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/ediscovery-assign-permissions?view=o365-worldwide

Selected Answer: D
Organization Management ist the only RBAC role that includes Search And Purge role for bulk removal

Finallly found this: 
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/ediscovery-assign-permissions?view=o365-worldwide
Organization Management ist the only RBAC role which allows bulk removal from data.
Therefore Search And Purge role is needed and this role is only available in Organization Management as you can see in the table behind the link


This role lets users perform bulk removal of data matching the criteria of a content search. For more information, see Search for and delete email messages in your organization.

The name of the role group in Compliance Center is eDiscovery Manager, but within this role group there are two subgroups: eDiscovery Manager and eDiscovery Administrator.

Assuming that the question refers to the name of the "parent" role group, the answer is correct.

eDiscovery Members can perform searches and place holds on mailboxes, SharePoint Online sites, and OneDrive for Business locations. Members can also create and manage eDiscovery cases, add and remove members to a case, create and edit Content Searches associated with a case, and access case data in eDiscovery (Premium).

The primary difference between an eDiscovery Manager and an eDiscovery Administrator is that an eDiscovery Administrator can access all cases that are listed on the eDiscovery cases page in the compliance portal. An eDiscovery manager can only access the cases they created or cases they are a member of.
--> for this case eDiscovery Administrator Role is necessary, because text says that the admin should access core and advanced cases and not only the case he created or is applied to

eDiscovery Members can perform searches and place holds on mailboxes, SharePoint Online sites, and OneDrive for Business locations. Members can also create and manage eDiscovery cases, add and remove members to a case, create and edit Content Searches associated with a case, and access case data in eDiscovery (Premium).

The primary difference between an eDiscovery Manager and an eDiscovery Administrator is that an eDiscovery Administrator can access all cases that are listed on the eDiscovery cases page in the compliance portal. An eDiscovery manager can only access the cases they created or cases they are a member of. 
--> for this case no ediscovery Administrator Role is necessary
C - ediscovery Administrator is the correct answer in my opinion

questions.question_text:
A company uses Exchange Online.
A user named Admin1 receives an error message when attempting a compliance search.
Admin1 needs to perform the following actions:
Create, edit, delete, and control access to Core and Advanced eDiscovery cases
Use the Content Search tool in the Microsoft 365 compliance center.
Place mailboxesâ€™ content on hold.
Perform bulk removal of data matching the criteria of a content search.
You need to determine the role group required by Admin1.
Which role group should you assign to Admin1?

discussion.content: Correct. See here https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/security-and-compliance/journaling/disable-enable-voicemail-missed-call-notifications

Found it: Set-TransportConfig -VoicemailJournalingEnabled $false/true


https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/security-and-compliance/journaling/disable-enable-voicemail-missed-call-notifications

questions.question_text:
A company uses Exchange Online and the United Messaging (UM) service. The company enables journaling for all users.
You discover voice mail and missed call notifications in the journaling mailbox.
You need to exclude voicemail and missed call notifications from the journaling mailbox.
Which cmdlet should you run?
